RT @SenWarren Trump‚Äôs Secretary of EDUCATION @BetsyDeVosED shrugged her billionaire shoulders and said it‚Äôs not her job to help keep track of COVID school reopening plans or outbreaks. Parents and teachers deserve better than this abdication of leadership. https://www.usnews.com/news/education-news/articles/2020-10-20/betsy-devos-not-my-job-to-track-schools-coronavirus-reopening-plans

As far as I see it, DeVos has a choice here, she can choose to do her job or not. 
 
If she wants schools to reopen in person safely, then she should be working with the Education Department to make it happen. Anything else is an abdication of duty.

If this sounds like an obvious step to you, that's because it is. 
 
Check out what @SenWarren and I wrote to DeVos, you can read our full letter at the link below. It explains what all this means in more detail:

This also means creating national reporting standards so it is possible to make comparisons. 

Think how much easier it would be for your kids‚Äô school to make decisions if they knew what health protocols work best and could compare their situation with others across the country.

To start with, let's start tracking how many cases are linked to schools and what safeguards schools are putting in place to reopen. 
 
That means coordinating with state and local governments to help with the great work that many are already doing.

This position is good news for DeVos, she gets to do less work. For everyone else, it means we‚Äôre in the dark about outbreaks in schools and best practices to reopening safely. 
 
@SenWarren and I are on the same page about this, so let‚Äôs talk how to make this situation better.

‚ÄúI'm not sure there's a role at the department to collect and compile that research.‚Äù
 
The dewonkified translation: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt believe in doing it."

You might be thinking that there is a national effort to track how schools are reopening in person so we can reopen as many as possible safely.

Best way to understand what the Tongass-specific exemption is all about? Read through the @forestservice announcement https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2020/10/29/2020-23984/special-areas-roadless-area-conservation-national-forest-system-lands-in-alaska.  üîç9/9

The @forestservice did not ignore public input. For nearly two years 267,000 comments were collected and reviewed. Most were from outside AK; most were form letters. @forestservice held numerous public meetings. üîç8/9
The exemption does NOT authorize stream and river pollution. @forestservice must mitigate for water pollution under state and federal laws, including the Tongass Timber Reform Act. üîç7/9

The Tongass exemption is NOT a sweetheart deal for timber operators. Large mills left the forest decades ago. There are 7 small-business and tribally-owned timber operators that employ 10 to 50 people each. üîç6/9
The Tongass will NOT be covered in logging roads. Only 49 additional miles are projected to be added to the entire forest (which is roughly the size of West Virginia) over the next 100 years. üîç5/9

Tongass harvest levels are NOT projected to increase as a result of the exemption. Those are set in the Tongass Forest Land & Resource Management Plan the Obama administration put in place. It still applies. üîç4/9

Under the new rule, only 188,000 acres‚Äîjust over 1% of the Tongass‚Äîwill be added to lands designated as ‚Äúsuitable‚Äù for timber production. (‚ÄúSuitable‚Äù means ELIGIBLE to be harvested; not that it will be harvested.)  üîç3/9
The Alaska-specific exemption will NOT result in widespread logging in the Tongass.üîç 2/9
üö® A lot of misinformation out there about the @forestservice rule on the #Tongass-specific exemption from the 2001 Roadless Rule. We‚Äôre busting some common myths. üîç 1/9
